articles.name: Set up a HubSpot integration
articles.title: Set up a HubSpot integration
articles.body:
Learn how to integrate your HubSpot account to feed leads from your Uberflip Hubs to HubSpot.

Â 

Before You Begin

  • To set up a HubSpot integration, you need to be in the Account Admin, Content Manager or Demand Generation user group(s).
  • You will also need a HubSpot account with Integration permissions.
  • To get the most out of the integration, you should be using Form CTAs to generate leads to send to HubSpot. To learn more about Form CTAs and how to set them up, see this article.

Another way to learn ðŸ“º

Check out the Uberflip Academy for a video overview on setting up a HubSpot integration.

About the HubSpot Integration

If you use HubSpot as part of your marketing tech stack, you can integrate it with your Uberflip account to get the most out of both platforms. Within your Hubs, Form CTAs are a highly effective way to generate leads â€” over 7x more effective than traditional landing pages. And once you've generated those leads, you need to do something with them â€” which is where Marketing Automation Platforms (MAPs) like HubSpot shine.

Form CTAs are designed to stream the leads they capture to a MAP, where you can make them part of your lead nurturing strategy. With HubSpot specifically, you have the option of adding these leads to your main contacts list, or to a Smart List of your choice.

When you integrate your account with HubSpot, we also automatically assign all visitors unique IDs (using cookies). This has two effects:

  • If a visitor fills out a Form CTA that is connected to HubSpot, the data they enter is tied to their cookie's ID. This allows us to automatically prefill that visitor's data on any other Form CTAs that they interact with.
  • Even if a user has not yet filled out a Form CTA, the cookie allows them to be tracked as they engage with your Hub content. If you set up the necessary custom fields in Hubspot, this allows you to track the Items that leads convert on.

In this article, we'll look at how to configure your account to integrate with HubSpot, along with optional steps to enable additional data collection.

Â 

Connect Your Account to HubSpot

All you need to do to integrate your Uberflip account with HubSpot is to connect them via the Uberflip app.

  1. Log into Uberflip and select any Hub
  2. In the sidebar menu, click Integrations
  3. You'll see a list of services that Uberflip can integrate with. Find HubSpot in the list and click Connect.
  4. A pop-up will appear. Click Connect.
  5. Another pop-up will open, taking you to the HubSpot login page. Log in with your HubSpot credentials.
  6. Follow HubSpot's prompts to grant permissions to Uberflip. When done, you'll be directed back to the Integrations page in Uberflip.
  7. You'll now see connected next to HubSpot in the Service Name list.

That's it! HubSpot is now connected to your account.

Â 

Optional: Enable Flipbook Tracking and Content Counters and Create Custom Fields

While the integration will work if you don't complete this step, it's highly recommended. Enabling Flipbook Tracking and Content Counters will allow you to track visitor behavior within your Hubs, and link it to specific contacts in HubSpot. If you choose to enable these options, you will also need to create some custom fields in HubSpot to be able to record the resulting data.

  1. On the Integrations page, click Edit next to HubSpot in the list column
  2. The Edit Settings window will open. Click on the two checkboxes next to Flipbook Tracking and Content Counters to enable these options
  3. Click Save
  4. Now, click Fields next to HubSpot
  5. The Service Fields window will open. Inside, you'll see a list of all the custom fields that need to be set up in HubSpot to record the data being sent from Uberflip
  6. By default none of the fields will exist yet, as indicated by the x in the Status column, and the red coloring. You'll also notice that some of the fields are marked as Required and some as Optional under the Necessity column:
    • Required fields are associated with either Flipbook Tracking or Content Counters and will only appear if you enabled these features in step 2 above.
    • Optional fields are related to tracking the Item a lead converted on; see the note below for more details.
  7. To be able to record data in a given field, you must first create it in HubSpot. To create a field, click on the +Add button beside it:
  8. Once a field has been successfully created, its line will turn grey, the +Add button will disappear, and a checkmark will appear beside it in the Status column:
  9. Continue clicking theÂ +AddÂ button for each field until you have added all the fields you want to use.

Optional Fields

You may have noticed that some of the fields in the Service Fields window are marked as Required and some as Optional. What's the difference?

Required fields are fields which are associated with the Flipbook Tracking/Content Counters options.Â These options require custom fields, so if you enable them, you must also create the corresponding fields. Note that if you do not enable these options, their fields will not appear in the Service Fields window.

Optional fields are related to tracking the Item a lead converted on. These are optional because, if you do not create them, the corresponding data will still be sent to HubSpot, but will simply not be recorded. Adding these optional fields will allow you to capture potentially valuable insights on which Items are your best performers in terms of conversions, so we strongly recommend adding them.

Â 

Next Steps

You're all set: you've successfully integrated your Uberflip account with HubSpot. Next, create some Form CTAs to begin generating leads.

articles.name: What changes cause an imported blog post to be disconnected from the original post?
articles.title: What changes cause an imported blog post to be disconnected from the original post?
articles.body:
Question

If I edit an Uberflip blog post that was imported from an external RSS feed, this will break the connection between the Uberflip version of the post and original external post, and as a result the Uberflip blog post will no longer update if I change the external post.

What specific changes will break the connection, and are there any changes that will not break it?

Â 

Answer

In general, most of the things you can change on an Uberflip blog Item will change the GUID of that Item and break the connection to the original (external) blog post. However, there are also some changes that will not affect the GUID, and which you can therefore make without disconnecting the Item from the blog post.

These breaking and non-breaking changes are outlined below:

Breaking Changes

While in the Edit Article view for an Item, changing any of the following will break the connection to the original blog post:

All tabs

  • Title field

Editor tab

  • Any change (i.e. changes to the article body text)

Metadata tab

  • Description field
  • Thumbnail URL field
  • Author dropdown
  • StatusÂ dropdown
  • Publish Date field
  • Hide Publish Date checkbox

SEO tab

  • Canonical URL field
  • SEO Title field
  • SEO Description field

Custom Code tab

  • Any change (i.e. adding/removing/modifying Custom Code)

Â 

Non-Breaking Changes

While in the Edit Article view for an Item, changing any of the following will NOT break the connection to the original blog post:

Metadata tab

  • URL Path field

Tags tab

  • Any change (i.e. adding/removing tags)

SEO tab

  • Auto redirect to Item's Canonical URL checkbox

Custom Labels tab

  • Any change (i.e. adding/removing/modifying Custom Labels)

articles.name: Views (Analytics > Engagement)
articles.title: Views (Analytics > Engagement)
articles.body:
General Info

What it is

Views is an indicator of how many times a page or piece of content was loaded by a visitor.Â 
Includes these data points
  • Item Views
  • Page Views
  • Stream Views
Collection Start

July 2019
Value

A count that distinguishes different types of pages being viewed.
Google AnalyticsÂ Equivalent

While page views is possible in Google Analytics, both stream views and item views would require custom dimensions to be set.

Â 

Item Views

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â A drill-able sum of the number of times items were viewed

Â 

Page Views

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â A drill-able sum of the number of times pages were viewed.

Â 

Stream Views

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â A drill-able sum of the number of times streams were viewed.Â Â 

Â

articles.name: Set Up an Olark Integration
articles.title: Set Up an Olark Integration
articles.body:
Use Olark Live Chat? Learn how to integrate your Olark with your Hub.

Â 

Before You Begin

  • To create an Olark integration, you need to be an Account Admin, Content Manager, or Developer/Designer.
  • You will also need an Olark account, and the ability to log in.
  • You'll be using Custom Code to create this integration. To learn more about Custom Code and how to use it, see this article.

Â 

About the Olark Integration

If you use Olark, you can install it on your Hub just like on any of your other websites. This will allow your Hub visitors to open live chats with you directly from your Hub.

To install Olark on your Hub, you embed a code snippet provided by Olark into your Hub using the Custom Code feature.

Â 

Install Olark on a Hub

  1. Before you can get started, you will need to get your Olark snippet. For instructions on how to get it, see this help article from Olark.
  2. Now, log in to your Uberflip account and navigate to the Hub where you want to create the Olark integration.
  3. In the sidebar menu on the left, click on Appearance, then click on Custom Code in the additional options that appear.
  4. Add a new Custom Code Block, or edit an existing Block. For detailed instructions on how to do that, go here.
  5. On the Edit Block page, click on theÂ Code tab and make sure theÂ Placement is set toÂ Body Bottom:
  6. Now, copy and paste the code snippet from Olark into the code box:
  7. Click on the Save button in the lower right.
  8. Lastly, toggle theÂ Enable Custom Code switch near the top of the Edit Block page to the on (green) position to enable the Custom Code Block and make the Olark code part of your Hub code:
  9. That's it! You have successfully set up the integration, and Olark live chat will now appear on your Hub.

articles.name: Can I automatically notify subscribers/followers when I publish a new blog post?
articles.title: Can I automatically notify subscribers/followers when I publish a new blog post?
articles.body:
Question

I want to give visitors to my Hub the ability to subscribe to my blog, so that they get an email notification whenever I publish a new post. Can I do this with Uberflip?

Â 

Answer

This functionality isn't built in to Uberflip, but there are various ways to achieve it using external tools. For example, if you're a Marketo user, one way to do this is by using Digesto. To learn how to set this up, see this article.

Another option is to use a task automation tool, such as Zapier, Microsoft Flow, automate.io, etc. These tools are designed to connect different software platforms, and to automatically perform an action whenever a specified trigger event occurs. While we can't provide detailed instructions for each such tool, a general setup might look like this:

  1. Use a Form CTA placed on your Uberflip blog to collect subscriber emails.
  2. Use emails collected with this Form CTA to populate a mailing list in your email marketing tool.
  3. Set up the task automation tool to monitor your blog's RSS feed (i.e. the RSS feed of your Uberflip Blog Stream) for new posts.
  4. Configure the task automation tool to send a new email each time a new post is published in that RSS feed, using your email marketing tool and the mailing list generated for this purpose (i.e. the one created using the Form CTA).

With this setup, your visitors can effectively subscribe to your blog by entering their email into the Form CTA, then receive an email notification whenever you publish a new post. For detailed instructions on how to set something like this up, please refer to the help resources of your preferred task automation tool.

articles.name: Session (Analytics > Engagement)
articles.title: Session (Analytics > Engagement)
articles.body:
General Info

What it is

Sessions engagement metrics capture KPIs for a single viewing period for a visitor.

A session is based on a short-livedÂ  60 minute cookie, which renewed based on last activity.Â  A user can navigate away from a page/or background a tab and as long as they return within an hour then that will be considered as the same session.
Includes these data points
  • Avg. Session Duration
  • Avg. Session Duration Formatted
  • Count Sessions
  • Items Per Session
  • Pages Per Session
Collection Start

July 2019 -Â Started collecting viewÂ 
December 2019 - Started collection Duration information
Value

Understand key information about sessions, both how many there were and also what those sessions entailed.
Google AnalyticsÂ Equivalent Google does track sessions.

Session duration is not very accurate in Google Analytics, as it is based strictly on the time stamp of page views.Â  Â Â 

Â 

Avg. Session Duration

Data Type:Â Calculated

Description:Â Â The Average length of user sessions, which is visualized in "mm:ss" format but exported as just "ss" format to allow for easy calculations.Â  The session duration is a sum of all active time viewing, which means if a tab is backgrounded then it does not count in the session duration.

Â 

Avg. Session Duration (Formatted)

Data Type:Â Calculated

Description:Â Â The Average length of user sessions, which is visualized in "mm:ss" and exported as the same "mm:ss" so it cannot be used for calculations.Â The session duration is a sum of all active time viewing, which means if a tab is backgrounded then it does not count in the session duration.

Â 

Count Sessions

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â Â The total number of sessions. A session is a viewing period by a visitor that uses the same short-lived cookie (1-hour).Â Â 


Items Per Session

Data Type: Calculated

Description:Â Â This is an average of the number of Items page views duration a session.Â  This is a very important KPI for differentiating what were navigation pages versus content pages.Â  Items are not distinct so a refresh of a page will count as another item view.

Â 

Pages Per Session

Data Type: Calculated

Description:Â Â This is an average of the number of URLs a user views during a session.Â  Pages are not counted as distinct so refreshing a page will count as another page view.Â Â 

Â

articles.name: Set Up a Sumo Integration
articles.title: Set Up a Sumo Integration
articles.body:
Integrating Sumo with your Hub is a quick and easy process that can open up a world of possibilities when it comes to lead generation, social sharing, analytics, traffic generation, audience communication, and more.

Â 

Before you Begin

  • To create this integration, you need to be an Account Admin or Content Manager.

Â 

Step 1: Install Sumo

  1. Go to https://sumo.com/ and sign up for a free account.
  2. When prompted during the registration, type in your Hub URL.
  3. Finally, you'll be prompted to install Sumo on your Hub using a bit of code. Copy the code, then log in to your Uberflip Hub.

Â 

Step 2: Add the Sumo Code to Your Hub

  1. Log in to Uberflip.
  2. Go to Hubs > Appearance > Custom Code.

  3. Click on the +Add Code button.

  4. The Add New Code window will appear. Begin by typing in a name and (optionally) description for this piece of custom code (e.g. "Sumo Integration"). Then, click on the Add Code button.
  5. This will take you to the Edit Custom Code view. Scroll down and click on the Code tab.

  6. Under Placement, use the dropdown to choose Head (it may already be selected by default).
  7. In the code field underneath, paste in the code you copied from Sumo earlier.
  8. Click on the Save button below the code field.
  9. Lastly, scroll back up and switch the toggle under Enable Custom Code to the on (green) position.

Â 

Step 3: Set up Sumo Apps

  1. Log back in to Sumo. Once logged in, click on the Visit Site button to load your Hub.



  2. When your Hub loads, you'll see a blue toolbar hovering on the right side of the page â€” don't worry, only you can see this toolbar! Click on the crown icon in the toolbar.

  3. A popup will appear. In it, click on Sumo Store.

  4. Browse through the Sumo Store and add apps that coincide with your marketing goals.
  5. When you add an app, you'll usually have to configure some options. For example, here's the setup screen for the Wallpaper App, which allows you to show visitors to your Hub a beautiful (and highly converting) front page when they visit for the first time:

  6. When you've finished configuring an app's options, click on the Save button.
  7. Finally, don't forget to activate any new app you add by toggling its status from Paused to Active.

And that's it â€” you've successfully integrated Sumo with your Hub!

articles.name: Link CTA Engagement(Analytics > Engagement)
articles.title: Link CTA Engagement(Analytics > Engagement)
articles.body:
General Info

What it is

Link CTA Engagement KPIs specifically around Link CTAs to track how visitors interact with them.Â 
Includes these data points
  • Link CTA Click-Through Rate
  • Link CTA Clicks
  • Link CTA Impressions
Collection Start

July 2019
Value

Depending on use, Link CTAs can be your primary KPI.Â  It is important to track if visitors saw your link CTAs and if they actually clicked on them
Google AnalyticsÂ Equivalent

Tracking CTA interactions would require custom events to be set up.

Â 

Link CTA Click-Through Rate

Data Type:Â CalculatedÂ 

Description: An average that indicates the percentage of visitors that had an impression of a CTA and subsequently clicked on it.

Â 

Link CTA Clicks

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â A sum of the number of times a visitor clicked on a Link CTA.

Â 

Link CTA Impressions

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â A sum of the number of times a visitor viewed a Link CTA, which was 50% on screenÂ  for at least 1 second.Â 

Â 

Â 

Â 

Â

articles.name: Why is the image cropped when I share an Item?
articles.title: Why is the image cropped when I share an Item?
articles.body:
Question

When I try to share content on social media or other websites, the thumbnail is not fully showing â€” it looks cut off. Why is this happening?

Â 

Answer

When you share content from your Hub on the web, the service you're sharing on will look at the shared content's Open Graph (OG) tags to determine what to display in the preview. In most cases, the thumbnail for the preview will be taken from the og:image tag. Uberflip automatically populates the og:image tag with an image based on what's being shared: for example, if you share an Item, the Item's thumbnail will be used. (For more information about how this works, see this article).

Many websites and other services expect the the og:image tag to contain a rectangular image, typically with an aspect ratio of around 1.9:1 (or sometimes 2:1). For example, 1.9:1 is what Facebook recommends. As a result, if the image from your Hub (e.g. the Item thumbnail) is taller than this, it will be cropped down to 1.9:1 when shared, and will appear cut off.

Unfortunately, there's currently no way to override the default image and use a custom image for the og:image tag. If you encounter this issue, you can resolve it by ensuring your Hub's images are as close as possible to a 1.9:1 ratio. You can also check out this article to see what image dimensions we generally recommend for your Hub.

articles.name: Form CTA Engagement (Analytics > Engagement)
articles.title: Form CTA Engagement (Analytics > Engagement)
articles.body:
General Info

What it is

Form CTA Engagement are KPIs for understanding how visitors interact with forms, generally utilized for lead collection.
Includes these data points
  • Form CTA Activations
  • Form CTA Convert Rate
  • Form CTA Impressions
  • Form CTA Submissions
  • Gated Form CTA Convert Rate
  • Gated Form CTA Impressions
  • Gated Form CTA Submissions
Collection Start

July 2019
Value

Depending on use, Form CTAs can be your primary KPI, especially if used for lead collection.Â  It is important to track if visitors saw your forms, which activated them and then subsequently which actually submitted the form.
Google AnalyticsÂ Equivalent

Tracking CTA interactions would require custom events to be set up.

Â 

Form CTA Activations

Data Type:Â CalculatedÂ 

Description:Â A sum of the number of times a Form CTA was clicked-into to access the actual form.Â 

Â 

Form CTA Convert Rate

Data Type:Â Calculated

Description:Â A percentage average of instances where a Form CTA had an Impression that subsequently led to a Form CTA Submission.Â  Â 

Â 

Form CTA Impression

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â A sum of the number of times a Form CTA was viewedÂ  50% on screen for at least 1 second.Â 

Â 

Form CTA Submission

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â A sum of the number of times a Form CTA was successfully filled out and delivered.

Â 

Gated Form CTA Convert Rate

Data Type:Â CalculatedÂ 

Description:Â A percentage average of instances where a Gated Form CTA (one that blocks access to content) had an Impression that subsequently led to a Form CTA Submission.Â  Â 

Â 

Gated Form CTA Impressions

Data Type:Â CalculatedÂ 

Description:Â A sum of the number of times a Gated Form CTA (one that blocks access to content) was viewedÂ  50% on screen for at least 1 second.Â 

Â 

Gated Form CTA Submission

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â A sum of the number of times a Gated Form CTA (one that blocks access to content) was successfully filled out and delivered.

Â

articles.name: What happens if I delete a blog that I have imported into my Hub with RSS?
articles.title: What happens if I delete a blog that I have imported into my Hub with RSS?
articles.body:
Question

I have created a Blog Stream in Uberflip by importing an RSS feed from my existing blog. If I now delete the original blog, what happens to the Blog Stream?

Â 

Answer

When you import a blog into your Hub with RSS, Uberflip pulls in existing posts on that blog to create content Items in the Blog Stream. These Items are created from the original blog's posts, but are completely separate and no longer tied to them after creation. As a result, deleting the original blog will not cause the corresponding Items to be deleted from the Blog Stream.

However, importing a blog with RSS also automatically brings in any associated images (post thumbnails and body images). Rather than importing and hosting these images, Uberflip displays them by linking to their location in the original blog. Deleting the original blog will also delete the images, which means that they will no longer be displayed in your Blog Stream.

If you have imported a blog into your Hub with RSS and want to delete the original blog, you will need to migrate the images to Uberflip. To do that, please contact us for help.

articles.name: Time on Page (Analytics > Engagement)
articles.title: Time on Page (Analytics > Engagement)
articles.body:
General Info

What it is

Time on Page is a calculation of the time spent viewing different content or pages in Uberflip.Â Â 

This metric is tracked in 2 second intervals and only registers when the page is actively being viewed.Â Â 
Includes these data points
  • Avg. Time on Page
  • Avg. Time on Page - Formatted
Collection Start

December 2019 - started collecting time on page
Value

Understand how long a visitor has been viewing a single piece of content or the average time multiple visitors have been viewing content.Â 
Google AnalyticsÂ Equivalent Google utilizes timestamps to calculate time on page.Â  This means that they can't give you the time spent in a single page view session or the last page in a session.


Avg. Time on Page

Data Type:Â Calculated

Description:Â Â The average length users actively viewing a page in "mm:ss" format but exported as just "ss" format to allow for easy calculations.Â Â 

Â 

Avg. Session Duration (Formatted)

Data Type:Â Calculated

Description:Â The average length users actively viewing a page in"mm:ss" and exported as the same "mm:ss" so it cannot be used for calculations.Â 

Â 

Count Sessions

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â Â The total number of sessions. A session is a viewing period by a visitor that uses the same short-lived cookie (1-hour).Â Â 


Items Per Session

Data Type: Calculated

Description:Â Â This is an average of the number of Items page views duration a session.Â  This is a very important KPI for differentiating what were navigation pages versus content pages.Â  Items are not distinct so a refresh of a page will count as another item view.

Â 

Â 

Pages Per Session

Data Type: Calculated

Description:Â Â This is an average of the number of URLs a user views during a session.Â  Pages are not counted as distinct so refreshing a page will count as another page view.Â Â 

Â

articles.name: If I hide an Item, will it still appear in search results?
articles.title: If I hide an Item, will it still appear in search results?
articles.body:
Question

When I hide an Item, can that Item still show up on Google?

Â 

Answer

Yes and no â€” it depends on whether the Item had already been indexed.

When you hide an Item, it is also automatically set to no-index (even if its Source Stream, or any of the Marketing Streams it appears in are indexable). This means that, from the point in time when the Item was hidden onward, it should not be indexed by Google.

However, if a hidden Item was indexed by Google before it was hidden, then that Item will still appear in search results until Google crawls your Hub again, which can take up to several months. If you need to remove the Item before this happens, Google provides a mechanism to do so: see this article from Google for details.

articles.name: Visitors (Engagement > Analytics)
articles.title: Visitors (Engagement > Analytics)
articles.body:
General Info

What it is

Visitor Engagement KPIs help you understand what is happening for visitors across multiple sessions level.

A visitor is someone with a long-lived cookie, which will remain in the user's browser for 365 days.Â  This is renewed every time they return.Â Â 
Includes these data points
  • New Visitors
  • Pages Per Visitor
  • Return Visitors
  • Unique Visitors
Data available after

Always in sync with database.
Value

Understand if your content is drawing new visitors or are they coming back for multiple sessions.Â  Also show how much content is being consumed by a visitor through multiple sessions.
Google Analytics equivalent/comparable Part of Google Analytics.

Â 

New Visitors

Data Type: Count

Description:Â Â A visitor is new if a browser cookie was seen only once.Â Â 


Pages Per Visitor

Data Type: Count

Description:Â Â The number of pages viewed by a visitor, which may include the same page multiple timesÂ Â 

Â 

Return Visitor

Data Type: Count

Description:Â Â A visitor is returned if their browser cookie has been seen before.

Â 

Unique Visitor

Data Type: Count

Description:Â Â A visitor is unique based on counting individual browser cookies

Â

articles.name: How often does the Embed Stream Tiles widget update to show new Items?
articles.title: How often does the Embed Stream Tiles widget update to show new Items?
articles.body:
Question

If I add a new Item to a Stream, how long will it take to appear on my Embed Stream Tiles widget?

Â 

Answer

The Embed Stream Tiles widget has its own cache that should update and display new Items in the Stream within 30 minutes of publishing the new content.Â Â

articles.name: Device Type (Analytics > Traffic)
articles.title: Device Type (Analytics > Traffic)
articles.body:
General Info

What it is

Device Type Indicates what the browser's user-agent says the visitor's device is.
Includes these data points
  • Device type
Collection Start

July 2019
Value

It's possible to understand if a session is from a particular device, including desktop, laptop, mobile, tablet or console.Â Â 
Google AnalyticsÂ Equivalent

Google Analytics provides this information as well as hardware information, which Uberflip Analytics will implement at a future date.

Â 

Device Type

Data Type: Dimension

Description:Â Identifies distinct device types based on a pre-defined list provided by Uberflip.Â Â

articles.name: How do I make images automatically expand to the width of the screen on different devices?
articles.title: How do I make images automatically expand to the width of the screen on different devices?
articles.body:
Question

How can I make my larger images expand to full width of the article section and display responsively on different screen sizes?

Â 

Answer

By default, a Hub Item's article section width is 840px maximum width and any image you upload that is 840px or wider, will display as full width of the article section and will automatically be responsive across different screen widths.

In a situation where your Hub design has the default Article section width set wider than 840px via custom code, you can edit the image width in the Item Editor>right click>image properties, and set the width and height of that image to 100%.Â  This will allow the image to expand to full width in that wider than usual article body.

Â 

Just note that if you are going to set width of an image to 100%, and the original image is not as wide as the width of your Article body, that image can display with deteriorated quality because you are stretching the image beyond its original dimensions

articles.name: Entry (Analytics > Traffic)
articles.title: Entry (Analytics > Traffic)
articles.body:
General Info

What it is

An "Entry" is the first page or content viewed during a session.Â Â 
Includes these data points
  • Entry Hub ID
  • Entry Item
  • Entry Item ID
  • Entry Item Thumbnail URL
  • Entry Page
  • Entry Stream
  • Entry Stream ID
  • Entry URL
Collection Start

July 2019
Value

By understanding how visitors are entering the content experience, it is possible to see information.Â 
Google AnalyticsÂ Equivalent

With google analytics, it's possible to utilize the Behavior functions to understand entry pages.

Â 

Entry Hub ID

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description:Â The unique identifier of the Hub where a session started.

Â 

Entry Item

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description:Â The distinct item title where a session started.

Â 

Entry Item ID

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description:Â The distinct item title where a session started.

Â 

Entry Item Thumbnail URL

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description:Â The thumbnail image representing the Entry Item.

Â 

Entry Page

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description:Â A styled Cell that combines the Item Title, Stream Title and URL for where a session started.

Â 

Entry Stream

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description:Â The distinct Stream title where a sessions started.

Â 

Entry Stream ID

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description:Â The distinct Stream ID where sessions started.

Â 

Entry URL

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description:Â The distinct URL where sessions started.

articles.name: Will an imported blog post be updated if the original blog post changes?
articles.title: Will an imported blog post be updated if the original blog post changes?
articles.body:
Question

I imported posts from a blog into a Blog Stream using RSS. If I make a change to a post in the original blog, will the corresponding Item in Uberflip be updated as well?

Â 

Answer

In general, yes: if you import a blog post into Uberflip and then subsequently edit that post in the source blog, the post in Uberflip will also be updated automatically. For this to happen, the following conditions must be met:

  • The blog Item must not be edited in Uberflip: as soon as any changes are made to an imported blog Item in Uberflip, it is considered distinct from the original blog post, and the link between them is severed permanently. (However, there are some things you can change without breaking the connection.)
  • The original blog post must still be available in the RSS feed: once the original blog post drops off the RSS feed, we are no longer able to query it for updates.
  • The original blog post must be within the most recent 200 items in the RSS feed: even if the original blog post is still in the RSS feed, Uberflip will only check the most recent 200 items for updates.

This applies only to modifying the original post: if you delete (rather than change) the original blog post, the imported Item will not be deleted, and will remain in Uberflip.

Finally, note that not all changes to the original blog post will trigger an update in Uberflip. See the Technical details section for specifics.

What about other types of Items?

The same principle applies to Items in all other types of Source Streams as well, e.g. Video, Social, and Docs (except Flipbooks): in general, modifying the source content will modify the imported Item in Uberflip, unless it has been modified in Uberflip first.

Â 

Technical details

If you're interested in the technical nuts and bolts behind this answer, here's how the process works:

  • When you import a blog post via RSS, Uberflip takes the unique identifier of the post (the GUID) and saves it to the External ID field of the corresponding Uberflip Item. This shared identifier is what links the original blog post with the Uberflip Item.
  • Every 1-2 hours (approx.), Uberflip runs an automation that checks the RSS feed connected to a Blog Stream for updates. In addition to looking for new posts in the feed, the automation also checks if any posts in the feed have the same GUID as an Item in the connected Blog Stream in Uberflip.
  • For any post and Item pair with matching GUIDs, the automation then looks at the <title>, <content:encoded>, and <pubDate> fields for that post in the RSS feed. If the values in any of these fields are different from the corresponding values on the Uberflip Item, the automation assumes that the blog post must have been updated since the Uberflip Item was created or last updated. In such cases, Uberflip reimports the updated blog post and updates the Item's corresponding values to match.
  • If you make any changes to an Uberflip Item that was imported from an RSS feed, Uberflip will remove that Item's original GUID from the External ID field, and replace it with a different GUID to indicate that the Uberflip Item is now distinct from the original blog post. This why Items that have been modified in Uberflip aren't updated if their original blog post is changed: because the post and Item no longer have matching GUIDs, the automation doesn't consider the blog post in the RSS feed to be the same as the Uberflip Item.

RSS feed changes that will not trigger an Uberflip Item update

The automation will only check the <title>, <content:encoded>, and <pubDate> fields in the RSS field for updates.

The other fields that are present on each post in the RSS feed (i.e. <link>, <description>, <author>, <dc:date>, and <category>) are ignored for this purpose, and therefore updating these fields will notÂ cause the Uberflip item to be updated (unless any of the <title>, <content:encoded>, and <pubDate> fields is also updated at the same time).

articles.name: Why are my autoplay videos muted?
articles.title: Why are my autoplay videos muted?
articles.body:
Question

Videos in my Hub that are set to autoplay are being muted by default. How can I ensure the video has sound when the video is playing?Â 

Â 

Answer

All major browsers now automatically mute videos that autoplay. For example, see this article from Google, which explains how this policy works in Chrome.

Because this is a policy thatâ€™s enforced by the visitorâ€™s browser, there is no way to force videos to autoplay with sound. If you want videos to autoplay, the visitor must manually unmute them.

However, browsers will not mute a video that does not autoplay (i.e. videos that the visitor cooses to play). As a result, you can disable autoplay to ensure that your videos play with sound enabled.

In Uberflip, you can disable autoplay on any video Source Stream (i.e. YouTube, Vimeo, Wistia, Vidyard or Brightcove). This is a Stream-level setting, so it will apply to all videos in the Stream, including when the videos are placed in Marketing or Sales Streams.

Here's how to disable autoplay for a video Stream:

  1. Under Content, find and open the video Source Stream (not a Marketing or Sales Stream).
  2. Click on the Options tab.
  3. Find the setting Disable auto playback:

  4. Turn this setting ON (green position). The change will save automatically, and will take effect right away.

Remember that this is a per-Stream setting, so you must configure it separately for each video source Stream in your Hub. Repeat the steps above for each Source Stream where you want to disable video autoplay.

Â 

Â

articles.name: Geography (Analytics > Traffic)
articles.title: Geography (Analytics > Traffic)
articles.body:
General Info

What it is

Geography data points identify the approximate location of a page view on based on IP address geo look-up.
Includes these data points
  • City
  • Country
  • Country Code
  • Country, Region, City
  • Region
Collection Start

July 2019
Value

Understand where traffic is originating from.Â Â 
Google AnalyticsÂ Equivalent

Provides its own geography tools based on IP address.

Â 

City

Data Type:Â Dimension

Description:Â The approximate city of where traffic is coming form.Â Â 

Â 

Country

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description:Â The approximate country of where traffic is coming form.Â Â 

Â 

Country Code

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description: A standardized 3-letter code using the ISO 3166 to put countries on a map.

Â 

Country, Region, City

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description: Condenses Country, City and Region into a dimensions.Â  Â 

Â 

Region

Data Type:Â DimensionÂ 

Description:The approximate state or province where traffic is coming form.Â Â 

Â 

Cities

Data Type: Cities

Description:Â A sum of cities where traffic originated from.Â Â 

Â 

Countries

Data Type: Cities

Description:Â A sum of cities where traffic originated from.Â Â 

Â 

Regions

Data Type: Countries

Description:Â A sum ofÂ  countries where traffic originated from.

articles.name: ID Fields (Analytics > Traffic)
articles.title: ID Fields (Analytics > Traffic)
articles.body:
General Info

What it is

Different unique identifiers (IDs) used to understand clear distinctions in traffic.
Includes these data points
  • Page View ID
  • Session ID
  • Visitor ID
  • Visitor UUID
Collection Start

July 2019
Value

These IDs can be used to specifically target specific instances and differentiate them.Â Â 
Google AnalyticsÂ Equivalent

With google analytics, it's possible to utilize the Behavior functions to understand entry pages.

Â 

Â 

Page View ID

Data Type: DimensionÂ 

Description:Â A unique identifier for a specific instance of a page view.Â 

Â 

Session ID

Data Type:Â Dimension

Description:Â A unique identifier for a specific session.Â Â 


Visitor ID

Data Type:Â Dimension

Description:Â A short back-end only unique identifier for differentiating specific visitors.

Â 

Visitor UUID

Data Type:Â Dimension

Description:Â A front-end exposed unique identifier that can be used to identify and delete visitors.Â Â

articles.name: UTM / URL (Anlaytics > Traffic)
articles.title: UTM / URL (Anlaytics > Traffic)
articles.body:
General Info

What it is

UTM / URL Anaytics provide Information pulled from URL parameters and referrals that indicate what the source of traffic was.

Standard UTM Parameters are utilized as shown here:

https://ga-dev-tools.appspot.com/campaign-url-builder/
Includes these data points

Dimensions

  • Full URL w/ Params
  • URL
  • URL Parameters
  • UTM Campaign
  • UTM Content
  • UTM Medium
  • UTM Source
  • UTM Source & Medium

Measures

  • Distinct URLs
  • UTM Campaigns
  • UTM Content
  • UTM Source & Medium
Collection Start

July 2019
Value

These parameters are vital in understanding what the source of traffic is coming from and where they are landing.
Google AnalyticsÂ Equivalent

Google provides extensive tools to understand referral trafficÂ 

Â 

Â 

Full URL w/ Params

Data Type: Dimension

Description:Â The entire URL as it's shown in the address bar.Â  This includes additional parameters a query strings, which are both standard UTM and custom.Â  This will show embed configurations as well.Â Â 

Â 

Full URL Parameters

Data Type: Dimension

URL Parameters:Â The end of a page view URL that includes UTM and other parameters.Â Â 

Â 

URL

Data type: Dimension

Description: The full URL of a page view.Â 

Â 

UTM Campaign

Data type: Dimension

Description: The UTM campaign parameter pulled from a page view.

Â 

UTM Content

Data type: Dimension

Description: The UTM content parameter pulled from a URL used to link to the destination. This includes identifiers such as paid keywords or more specific identifiers for campaigns.

Â 

UTM Medium

Data type: Dimension

Description: The UTM medium parameter pulled from the URL used to link to the destination.

The medium refers to the type of platform referrals came from.Â  If the medium is in parentheses such as (none), (organic), (referral) then that means they were inferred by Uberflip. Those without such as email, referral, or social were explicitly provided.

Â 

UTM Source

Data type: Dimension

Description: The UTM medium parameter pulled from the URL used to link to the destination.

The source is the actual platform referring traffic.Â  This includes Google.com, yourwebsite.com, and if it's (direct) then that means someone typed in the actual URL manually.

Â 

Distinct URLs

Data Type: Count

Description:Â A drill-able count of Distinct page view URLs that can be used to identify all the URLs where an item might be displayed.Â 

Â 

UTM Campaigns

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â A sum of the number of distinct campaigns pulled from the campaign UTM parameter.Â  Campaigns are either manually set or set by your Marketing automation software / ad server.

Â 

UTM Source & Mediums

Data Type:Â Count

Description:Â A sum of the number of distinct UTM Source & Medium pairs.Â 

Â
